Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2015 04:15AM - edited Jul 3, 2015 04:19AM by art15 My wife is undergoing neoadjuvant chemo for an IDC/TNBC/metaplastic with squamous 3.5cm tumor, she's on Carboplatin-Gemzar, after 2 cycles of 6, her ultrasound yeasterday the tech said "it's a fluid-filled center now... looks like a cyst... the lymph nodes are smaller..." is this solid mass turning to liquid promising? The Onco gets the report tomorrow (Scripps/ San Diego California) Onco said only seen this subtype of TN 3 times before.

Posts.Title: my wife/ new lump in other breast art15 art15

Posts.Content: art15 wrote: My wife just had 7 years and a clear PET scan end of last yr. She had some ILC/IDC stage 2B/lumpectomy/chemo/rads in 2008.Digital mammo clear(lobular hard to see, I know) in Feb this year, breast exam Mar5 w/ new doc she felt nothing, then 6 weeks later she has a 1/2 egg mass above her nipple on healthy breast, smooth, no pain, hard but moves. Scripps got her right in for mammo, they then came up with an immediate apt surprisingly for USound, scared. Her new doc says report it's 3.5cm solid w/ vascular properties, a few abnotrmal swollen lymph nodes too... really devastated this came on so quick, Monday is needle core biopsy (Scripps /Medicare both 65 yrs old this yr) Pretty much know it's not a cyst,etc(liquid) but don't see any B9 necrosis ones that grow that fast (6-8weeks?) size of walnut. Her bc in 2008 was in lobular fingers, this is defined mass, wish us luck please, really down about this. She got lymphedema and has to wear a compression sleeve/glove almost always and really is scared if another armpit surgery ,thx for reading and support very much. Married 43 years this May 26 so this hurts I guess. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: my wife/ new lump in other breast art15 art15

Posts.Content: May 7, 2015 07:37AM art15 wrote: Sorry to report doctor called that it's "invasive cancer" and needs to come out, she's pushing thru approval for surgeon apt. No details yet, she wanted to get surgeon request to insurance right away. The lymph node biopsy is "benign" which is good news -except we know a SNB is probably needed before knowing. Thanks for all prayers and thoughts, it means a lot. She went thru this in 2008 other breast ( IDC+ILC stage 2B, 2 lumpectomies, (6) chemo + radiation, and we're prepared to do it again.
Posts.Title: my wife/ new lump in other breast art15 art15

Posts.Content: May 11, 2015 04:22PM - edited May 11, 2015 04:40PM by art15 Met with surgeon today. The path report says 3.5cm invasive poorly differentiated carcinoma w/ focal squamous features.The lymph node is benign on needle aspiration. The ER, PgR & HER2 = all NEG (not good I guess) The doc says since her other breast cancer 7 yrs ago on other side was ER positive, this is a new cancer. He recommends masectomy on that side. Wants immediate MRI on both sides to see extent, wife has "thickening of tissue on original side uner arm, Kaiser said no bc but they missed a lot on mammos, incl orig. This is Scripps. He wants her to see the oncologist he works with to see feasibility of chemo b4 surgery, but why? Thought that was for shrinkage b4 lumectomy. Wife not totally happy so called for another opinion referall, this doc says 1-2 weeks to decide is ok, but this is Triple-Neg and came out of nowhere so not very sure here. He says will try and not do lymph node dissection since she got lymphedema on her other side, and we're not sure about a needle biopsy not being conclusive on the node being negative, and he said we don't know if it's the sentinel node, we can take out a few later. He wants to get his oncologist involved and the MRI is needed in the event she decides on another doctor anyway, but we both agree only 2 opinions now and move on because this is a more aggressive tumor. thanks all.
Posts.Title: my wife/ new lump in other breast art15 art15

Posts.Content: May 15, 2015 01:35PM art15 wrote: Thanks for the reply, the pathology report indicated "squamous" and possibly a "metaplastic mammary carcinoma" , the doctor said "we are seeing more of this... it's treatable..." and my wife is having some scans (MRI today) and I believe the doctor's oncologist plans on chemo to shrink first this is a new cancer, not the same as other breast. Not a recurrance, or metastisis.
Posts.Title: my wife/ new lump in other breast art15 art15

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 03:39PM - edited Jun 10, 2015 03:47PM by art15 I think it's good you're referred to a breast specialist, as my wife was. We went to an appointment where the surgeon was recognized locally, but he did not do only breast surger, he did maybe 60-70%, the rest was hernias, etc, my only advice is that you call and ask to be put on the list for this breast surgeon for any cancellation. A cyst is obvious on an ultrasound, the ultrasound also shows if there is vascular activity, using the blood system, tumors, like my wife's are vascular and NOT liquid, but solid, they can tell that from ultrasound, the suspicious ones are solid/vascular , if liquid center, it's most likely benign, and you'll be alright...generally. G
Posts.Title: Am I being paranoid or do I need to pursue this? y1981m art15

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2015 04:53PM - edited Nov 5, 2015 04:57PM by art15 For what it's worth, I think the surgeon apt is great, try to direct it to one specializing in bc if you can, but that's a start, you can see your Primary CP after that, next Thurs is here soon. My wife saw her PCP today, after masectomy, which brought her up to date, she has some eye bacteria, maybe b/c of chemo, she gave her an Rx drops, she moved up her oncologist apt to tomorrow, to discuss the surgery pathology report, I think the breast surgeon and oncologist are key, in that order, in our long journey, and trusting them.
Posts.Title: Not Sure What To Do Next cmh417 cmh417

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2015 05:26PM - edited Jun 26, 2015 05:28PM by art15 Sorry if you have a problem with a husband responding... my wife had/has dense breast tissue, the mammo, even the digital mammo, she has dense breast tissue, and she originally had IDC w/ some lobular, which is hard to see in the mammo, but it does NOT confirm any carcinoma, that needs an ultrasound and maybe an MRI, you do not to worry between now and next week, nothing is going to happen that is worse... the needle biopsy is a good idea, my wife never had discomfort, after they numb it , then you know for sure. Keep everyone advised here, ok?

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2015 01:54PM art15 wrote: As a husband of my wife- that's now in her second bout with breast cancer, I don't think there's an "overly-cautious" ... I would request a digital mammo in 3 months instead of 6 , for piece of mind, you could request that anyway.
Posts.Title: Not Sure What To Do Next cmh417 cmh417

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2015 03:44PM - edited Oct 29, 2015 03:53PM by art15 I noticed you are only 24. Cancer takes about 7 years to develop, except in rare case, I think there are women on this board who might give you better guidance, cellulitis sounds probable. I'm not a doctor. Radiologists are usually very reliable. It's not rocket-science for them to tell if a lump/spot is cystic (liquid center) or a solid tumor with vascular properties, this is probably NOT your situation at your age, don't panic now.
Posts.Title: Not Sure What To Do Next cmh417 cmh417

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 05:12PM - edited Jun 10, 2015 05:18PM by art15 There are articles written that DCIS is NOT cancer, but, "pre-cancer" and if the statistics for chemotherapy were to exclude those patients that were DCIS, the survival rate would plummet, I read this, it's out there that the inclusion of DCIS patients who opted for radical surgery/chemotherapy makes the statistics look better for chemo drugs, and this is what the drug companies want, I'm not saying chemo doesn't work, but there is a debate out there about DCIS included in some chemo/survival results, when there is a voice out there that says radical surgery/chemo is not necessary if dx is DCIS, and not yet IDC. If I'm wrong, please respond ,respectfully tia. I read this at Poolsters Breast Clinic, La Jolla, CA library, while I was waiting for my wife, fyi. I have no idea if this is what the drug companies want, that's a conspiracy which I don't believe, but DCIS patient imput who chose chemo makes the results look better is all I'm saying.
Posts.Title: Feeling overwhelmed... Js5 Js5

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 01:55PM art15 wrote: DCIS is not invasive, you caught it early. I think you should not be pushed. My wife had IDC w/ some lobular stage 2B, grade 3, and her lumpectomy was fine after 8 years. She had only one lymph node cancerous, a .3mm in a 3 mm node, she had (4) chemo cycles and radiation, you haven't said if lymph nodes involved, if not, thank God you caught this early and we wish you the best.
Posts.Title: Feeling overwhelmed... Js5 Js5

Posts.Content: May 7, 2015 05:12PM - edited May 7, 2015 05:33PM by art15 My wife had a IDC with(ILC) Lobular Invasive Carcinoma/ or "Infiltrating Lobular Carcinoma" lump. I talked to the surgeon before and after, it's a good idea if a spouse or significant other is there, but I am not preaching...this was at Kaiser Perm San Diego/ Dr Herman/ he said when excising lymph nodes or cancerous tissue it's " mainly on feel... it's like an apple with a rotten spot, ... he said he "feels" the lymph nodes (they are in tissue)(after all the radiology, and a great "nuclear dept, which uses a redioactive iv to locate problems...)) as it is not clear where the surgeon "sees" , ...this is not an exact science by any means, Dr. Herman tried to take enough margin(lumpectomy) which was excessive because it was/is lobular(ILC) cancer... my wife calls him a butcher... surely he is/was NOT because she has not had a recurrence in that side- same breast...or on the excised margin... Dr. Herman told me(in waiting room after) if my wife did not want a mastectomy, he would do a lumpectomy, which he called "breasted conserving surgery" but these are choices we are faced with again after 7 years , but i think it is valuable to not only ( have a friend or spouse) to talk to these medical professionals, they are receptive, they want to put you at ease, they will explain why they have resolved to do a certain surgery this is my experience, but I have been semi-retired and now retired, so my acute understanding of our situation is probly not available to some people, this takes time, lots of time... hope this helps .. Art

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2015 10:43AM art15 wrote: Amybeth68- my wife was 58 in 2008 when she was diagnosed w/ IDC Stage 2B w/ lobular (ILC) bc. Kaiser missed it on her mammo. They didn't have digital mammograms then, so it's better now w/ dense breast tissue, ask for that. The best way to determine is still a biopsy, if you need that they probably will do that before an MRI, I think that was the order, I can't remember, I think the MRI was to see the extent before the lympectomy. We hope it's something benign, and you can put this behind you. As I remember, my wife still had a lump, it's just that w/ lobular,(ILC) it puts out fingers/strands, so she needed a 2nd lumpectomy to get clear margins.
Posts.Title: Breast thickening-Referred for mammo and US Amybeth68 art15

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2015 07:06PM art15 wrote: It might be just a benign fatty condition. My wife had lobular cancer, which put out fingers, causing a thickening and in dense breast tissue, is hard to see, so if they think the ultrasound looks suspect, ask for a MRI, which is often the only way to see the "lobular"(ILC) cancer" but that take years to develop, and we hope this is a benign condition and a good outcome for you!
Posts.Title: Breast thickening-Referred for mammo and US Amybeth68 art15

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2015 02:36PM - edited Aug 4, 2015 02:37PM by art15 My wife had a delay in ultrasound results, and it was very important to know if chemo was shrinking the cancer, the radiologist had not signed off on it, but you can call your breast Doc and make sure he/she gets the radiologists report, I think it goes to him first, you might shave a week off the time good luck hope all benign, check-in w/ radiologist so you know when to expect it sent to your doc.
Posts.Title: Had hospital appointment now waiting again Mrsl2004 art15

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 10:40AM - edited Jun 10, 2015 10:44AM by art15 Kaiser is not good with cancer. They do not like to refer for MRI. The PET/CT scan 10 months ago showed uptake in her other armpit, not the on she had cancer on the other side 8 yrs ago. They said "no follow up needed" They could have had her in for U/S, if those lymph nodes were abnormal, they could have shown "no fatty lipium" a dead-giveaway for carcinoma...We thought it was an "artifact" from PET injection, as my wife has weak veins and they had to do twice. Scripps or any other group will never implicate another medical group, there is a silent protection vs medical malpractice. My wife is doing well after 1 cycle of carbo/gemzar +Nuelasta shot, we won't know until after her 2nd cycle if the tumor has shrunk, thanks for asking that is very kind. Scripps is better for cancer care, in our experience. I would NEVER trust Kaiser, even though I am happy w/ Primary Care,but they have made huge life-or-death mistakes, with my wife, just my opinion,
Posts.Title: got abnormal mammogram in my other breast today gretchy grammakathy

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 10:07AM art15 wrote: My wife has dense breast tissue, Kaiser missed her early spot, you are right to be aggressive and ask for MRI if needed. With dense breasts, mammo does not see well. If ILC, (Invasive/infiltrating lobular cancer,) mammo does not see. The insurance companies do not like to do MRI because then they must do biopsies, but you are in good hands to pursue this, a needle biopsy will put your mind at rest, request copies of all work done.
